results.title: Behaviour patterns at one year
results.creator_credit: Arnold Gesell and Yale Clinic of Child Development
results.brief_description: Portrays the behaviour patterns of a normal infant fifty-two weeks of age. The baby’s manipulation and other reactions to one, two, three, and ten cubes are interpreted and discussed by the narrator. Continues with the study of other test situations involving a cup and a spoon, cup and cubes, pellet, pellet and bottle, ball, ring and string, paper and crayon, a performance box, and a form board.

results.title: Behavior of gases
results.creator_credit: Gene Kearney, John Friedman, Lee Grodzins and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
The Brownian motion as applicable to smoke particles is shown by photomicrography and compared with a mechanical analogue. Animation is used to develop a model for gas pressure based on chaotic molecular motion. This chaotic motion is contrasted with the orderly behaviour of gases as shown by an experiment illustrating Boyle’s Law. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Behaviour modification: teaching language to psychotic children (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: O-Ivor Lovaas, Robert Aller and Appleton-Century-Crofts
results.brief_description: Shows typical speech patterns of autistic and schizophrenic children, and discusses correction of these before learning begins. Demonstrates instruction methods in imitation of sounds, labelling of objects, discrimination between alternatives, recall of experiences, and development of some spontaneity.

results.title: Begonia festival
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Boolari Films and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: At the annual Begonia Festival, Ballarat becomes a city of flowers, music, dancing and drama centred on the famous begonia display. Mr. Tom Beaumont, the curator of the glass house in the Botanic Gardens, tends the many blooms. He is a world authority on begonia culture. Highlights of the display are a thousand double blooms and six hundred distinctive single varieties. In the gardens we see a fine display of salvias, gladioli and dahlias. Young and old admire the wonderful colour and variety of the Botanic Gardens and also the open air art exhibition. Commentary by John Morgan.

results.title: Begone dull care
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren, Evelyn Lambart and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A lively interpretation of jazz music played by the Oscar Peterson Trio. The music is visually represented in a series of abstract lines and shapes, hand painted directly on to the film, culminating in a fast and furious explosion as the tempo quickens. One of the high points of jazz in cinema (and of McLaren’s career).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norman McLaren, Evelyn Lambart and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Beginnings of vertebrate life
results.creator_credit: William Kay and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Reveals complex processes by which a one-celled egg, becomes a many-celled, highly organized individual. Shows by means of time-lapse photography and animation the embryonic development of a small fresh water fish, Oryzias latipes, illustrating early processes of fertilization, cell division and formation of the blastula.

results.title: The Beginnings of the cinema
results.creator_credit: British Film Institute and National Film Archive (Great Britain)
results.brief_description: This is a representative collection of short films made between 1896 and 1903, comprising: ‘A Train entering a station’ (from the first Lumiere program); ‘The Derby - on the road to Epsom’, R.W. Paul’s film of the 1896 Derby; ‘The Brighton fire’; ‘Panorama of Calcutta’; ‘The Vanishing lady’; ‘Pienture a L’envers’; ‘The Music eccentric’; ‘A Chess dispute’; and ‘The Miller and the sweep’.

results.title: Beginnings of conscience
results.brief_description: A driver obeys traffic signs even when there is no one in sight because he has a conscience, instilled since childhood by his daily life at home, school, and work. The socialization process is analysed in terms of the life of an “average” boy. Shows influence of parental approval or disapproval, peer acceptance or rejection, and forms of discipline in various social situations. In a nutshell, this film implores the “educational aspect of punishment.” It explains that without socialisation, and without the sanctions used to achieve it, there would be no basis for moral order in human society.

results.title: Beginning wheel techniques
results.brief_description: An introduction to the fundamentals of pottery. Wheel throwing is simplified by using the clock dial as a means of reference. Techniques shown making a cylinder are sticking, mastering, centering, opening, raising and finishing. The potter’s rib is demonstrated. The needle point tool is used to level and to test for centre bottom thickness. Similar techniques are shown for bowl and plate forms.
